pageProps.contentHtml:
argument principle, Blaschke products

Let a1,a2,…,ana_1, a_2, \ldots, a_na1​,a2​,…,an​ be n≥1n \geq 1n≥1 points in the disc D={∣z∣<1}\D = \set{\abs{z} < 1}D={∣z∣<1} (possibly with repetitions), so that the function

B(z)=∏j=1nz−aj1−aj‾zB\p{z} = \prod_{j=1}^n \frac{z - a_j}{1 - \conj{a_j}z}B(z)=j=1∏n​1−aj​​zz−aj​​

has nnn zeros in D\DD. Prove that the derivative B′(z)B'\p{z}B′(z) has n−1n - 1n−1 zeros in D\DD.
Solution.

Let φa ⁣:D→D\func{\phi_a}{\D}{\D}φa​:D→D be the Blaschke factor which maps a∈Da \in \Da∈D to 000. Notice that

φa(1/z‾)‾=((1/z‾)−a1−a/z‾)‾=(1−az‾z‾−a‾)‾=1−a‾zz−a=1φa(z)\begin{aligned} \conj{\phi_a\p{1/\conj{z}}} = \conj{\p{\frac{\p{1/\conj{z}} - a}{1 - \conj{a/z}}}} &= \conj{\p{\frac{1 - a\conj{z}}{\conj{z} - \conj{a}}}} \\ &= \frac{1 - \conj{a}z}{z - a} \\ &= \frac{1}{\phi_a\p{z}} \end{aligned}φa​(1/z)​=(1−a/z​(1/z)−a​)​​=(z−a1−az​)​=z−a1−az​=φa​(z)1​​

which gives the identity φa(z)φa(1/z‾)‾=1\phi_a\p{z}\conj{\phi_a\p{1/\conj{z}}} = 1φa​(z)φa​(1/z)​=1. Thus, B(z)B(1/z‾)‾=1B\p{z}\conj{B\p{1/\conj{z}}} = 1B(z)B(1/z)​=1 by multiplying all the terms together. Taking the derivative on both sides, we obtain

B′(z)B(1/z‾)‾−1z2B(z)B′(1/z‾)‾=0,\begin{aligned} B'\p{z}\conj{B\p{1/\conj{z}}} - \frac{1}{z^2} B\p{z}\conj{B'\p{1/\conj{z}}} = 0, \end{aligned}B′(z)B(1/z)​−z21​B(z)B′(1/z)​=0,​

which tells us that if B(z)≠0B\p{z} \neq 0B(z)=0, then B′(z)=0  ⟺  B′(1/z‾)=0B'\p{z} = 0 \iff B'\p{1/\conj{z}} = 0B′(z)=0⟺B′(1/z)=0. Another calculation gives us

B′(z)B(z)=∑j=1n1−∣aj∣2(z−aj)(1−aj‾z).\frac{B'\p{z}}{B\p{z}} = \sum_{j=1}^n \frac{1 - \abs{a_j}^2}{\p{z - a_j}\p{1 - \conj{a_j}z}}.B(z)B′(z)​=j=1∑n​(z−aj​)(1−aj​​z)1−∣aj​∣2​.

First, assume that B(0)≠B′(0)≠0B\p{0} \neq B'\p{0} \neq 0B(0)=B′(0)=0 and that BBB has distinct zeroes. Multiplying the above by ∏j=1n(z−aj)(1−aj‾z)\prod_{j=1}^n \p{z - a_j}\p{1 - \conj{a_j}z}∏j=1n​(z−aj​)(1−aj​​z), we get a polynomial equation P(z)=0P\p{z} = 0P(z)=0 of degree 2n−22n - 22n−2. Since the zeroes of BBB are precisely a1,…,ana_1, \ldots, a_na1​,…,an​, PPP does not vanish at any of these points, so P(z)=0  ⟺  B′(z)=0P\p{z} = 0 \iff B'\p{z} = 0P(z)=0⟺B′(z)=0.

Given a zero zjz_jzj​ of B′B'B′ in D\DD, however, we know that B′(1/zj‾)B'\p{1/\conj{z_j}}B′(1/zj​​) is a zero of B′B'B′ outside of D\DD. Since B′B'B′ has 2n−22n - 22n−2 zeroes, it follows that half of them are in the disk and half are outside the disk, i.e., B′B'B′ has n−1n - 1n−1 zeroes in D\DD.

In the general case, by perturbing aaa in φa\phi_aφa​, we may approximate BBB uniformly on compact sets by a Blaschke product BεB_\epsilonBε​ such that Bε(0)≠Bε′(0)≠0B_\epsilon\p{0} \neq B_\epsilon'\p{0} \neq 0Bε​(0)=Bε′​(0)=0 and the roots of BεB_\epsilonBε​ are all distinct. By the Cauchy integral formula,

∣B′(z)−Bε′(z)∣≤12π∫∂B(z,r)∣B(ζ)−Bε(ζ)∣∣ζ−z∣2 dζ≤∥B−Bε∥L∞r.\abs{B'\p{z} - B_\epsilon'\p{z}} \leq \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_{\partial B\p{z,r}} \frac{\abs{B\p{\zeta} - B_\epsilon\p{\zeta}}}{\abs{\zeta - z}^2} \,\diff\zeta \leq \frac{\norm{B - B_\epsilon}_{L^\infty}}{r}.∣B′(z)−Bε′​(z)∣≤2π1​∫∂B(z,r)​∣ζ−z∣2∣B(ζ)−Bε​(ζ)∣​dζ≤r∥B−Bε​∥L∞​​.

So, it follows that Bε′B_\epsilon'Bε′​ converges uniformly to B′B'B′ on compact sets and similarly, Bε′′B_\epsilon''Bε′′​ converges uniformly to B′′B''B′′ on compact sets. By uniform convergence,

∫∂DB′′(z)B′(z) dz=lim⁡k→∞∫∂DBε′′(z)Bε′(z) dz=n−1.\int_{\partial\D} \frac{B''\p{z}}{B'\p{z}} \,\diff{z} = \lim_{k\to\infty} \int_{\partial\D} \frac{B_\epsilon''\p{z}}{B_\epsilon'\p{z}} \,\diff{z} = n - 1.∫∂D​B′(z)B′′(z)​dz=k→∞lim​∫∂D​Bε′​(z)Bε′′​(z)​dz=n−1.

Since BBB is holomorphic on D\DD, it follows that B′B'B′ has no poles inside of D\DD. Thus, by the argument principle, B′B'B′ has precisely n−1n - 1n−1 zeroes in D\DD, which completes the proof.
